summary: This article discusses the MicroBlocks BLE extension for MIT App Inventor, which simplifies connecting to microcontrollers via Bluetooth Low Energy. summary: This document introduces Microblocks, a free, open-source graphical programming environment similar to Scratch, designed for real-time execution on microcontrollers like Micro:bit, ESP32/ESP8266, and Raspberry Pi Pico. It highlights the use of Microblocks with the FoxBit development board and XGO robot dog, showcasing how users can control actions, sensors, and AI functionalities by dragging and dropping code blocks.

summary: The article is about FlowUs, which is presented as a one-stop knowledge creation and distribution platform. It states that the current browser environment cannot run the content and advises copying the link to open it in another browser.

The article compares several graphical hardware programming platforms, highlighting MicroBlocks as a standout project due to its support for interactive programming and powerful virtual machine. It contrasts MicroBlocks with other platforms like MakeCode, Makeblock, and Scratch, emphasizing MicroBlocks' unique approach to seamlessly integrate interactive and embedded programming, facilitating exploration and creativity for makers.

summary: MicroBlocks originated from John Maloney's explorations of programming systems for children, drawing inspiration from Logo, Smalltalk, and other projects. The immediate inspiration was a presentation on the BBC micro:bit, leading to a collaboration between John Maloney, Jens Mönig, and Bernat Romagosa to create a live programming system that avoids "download fatigue".

summary: MicroBlocks is a free, Scratch-like blocks programming language designed for learning physical computing with educational microcontroller boards. It distinguishes itself through a combination of live programming and autonomous operation, allowing users to instantly see results and deploy code on various boards without compilation delays.

entities.name: MicroBlocks
entities.description: A free, Scratch-like blocks programming language for learning physical computing.

entities.name: micro:bit
entities.description: An educational microcontroller board compatible with MicroBlocks.

entities.name: Adafruit Circuit Playground Express
entities.description: An educational microcontroller board compatible with MicroBlocks.

entities.name: Live Programming
entities.description: A feature of MicroBlocks that allows code to run immediately without compilation.

entities.name: Autonomous Operation
entities.description: A feature of MicroBlocks that allows code to run independently after being downloaded to the board.

entities.name: Parallelism
entities.description: The ability to run separate scripts for each task simultaneously in MicroBlocks.

entities.name: Portability
entities.description: MicroBlocks scripts are portable across many different boards.

entities.name: Virtual Machine
entities.description: Executes the user's code on the microcontroller by interpreting bytecodes.

entities.name: Raspberry Pi
entities.description: A single-board computer that can run the MicroBlocks virtual machine.

entities.name: NeoPixels
entities.description: An output device supported by MicroBlocks libraries.

entities.description: An output device supported by MicroBlocks libraries.

summary: This article discusses porting MicroBlocks, a Scratch-like block programming language, to the BeagleConnect Freedom board. It details the process, which involves leveraging the Arduino Core API module for Zephyr and outlines steps for flashing images and building MicroBlocks firmware, highlighting the ongoing efforts to merge support upstream for easier porting in the future.

summary: The article introduces MicroBlocks, a graphical programming language similar to Scratch, designed for physical computing and hardware programming. It highlights the advantages of MicroBlocks, such as its 'click-to-download' functionality, parallel task support, cross-platform compatibility, and user-defined library creation, focusing on its application with the KittenBot Grape board.
